entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - From Provisioning to Intelligent Applications
entry.content:
Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud

In this blog, we will try to go over the Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and then the Components and Building Blocks of SAP BDC.

SAP BDC is a fully managed software-as-a-service (SaaS) offering from SAP designed to address this need of managing vast volumes of data originating from diverse systems. It consolidates and governs all SAP data while seamlessly integrating third-party sources, delivering contextualized, trusted data to business leaders for more impactful decision-making. By harmonizing mission-critical data into a unified semantic layer, the platform eliminates the overhead of data extraction and replication.  Supporting a wide range of use cases across industries and business functions, SAP BDC ensures that data is consistently accessible, secure, and ready for advanced analytics.

Key Aspects of SAP Business Data Cloud

  • Intelligent Applications: AI-driven apps that leverage your data and business context to automate processes, adapt dynamically, and drive transformative outcomes in real time.
  • Data Products: Prebuilt, customizable, and governed data assets that come enriched with business semantics, documentation, and APIs‚Äîaccelerating deployment across a wide range of use cases.
  • Business Data Fabric: A comprehensive data and analytics foundation that integrates SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, modernized SAP Business Warehouse, data engineering capabilities, and AI/ML innovations through SAP Databricks.
  • AI-Enriched Decision Making: Enterprise-grade tools that deliver responsible, context-aware AI for reporting and analytics ‚Äîempowering smarter, faster decisions.

Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Source Systems:  SAP BDC connects seamlessly to various source systems‚Äîsuch as SAP S/4HANA‚Äîto identify and extract key business data entities. These include tables, views, and other structures that contain mission-critical data across domains like HR, finance, supply chain. By integrating with these systems, SAP BDC ensures that foundational business data is readily available for analytics, governance, and intelligent application development.

Foundational Services in SAP Business Data Cloud: Within SAP BDC, data extracted from source systems flows into the Foundation Services layer. This foundational component is responsible for ingesting, integrating, cleansing, and harmonizing both structured and unstructured data. It ensures that the data is properly aligned and enriched as part of SAP-managed Data Products, forming the backbone of trusted, analytics-ready information across the SAP BDC landscape.

SAP Datasphere: SAP Datasphere serves as the modeling and governance layer atop the BDC Semantic Layer. It provides a robust set of tools for designing analytical data models, defining business logic, managing data lineage, enforcing governance and security. In addition to its core modeling capabilities, SAP Datasphere supports machine learning and AI extensions, making it a foundational component for advanced analytics and intelligent decision-making. Datasphere acts as the data engine behind SAP Analytics Cloud, feeding it with both prebuilt and custom insights for reporting and visualization. It also enables customers to create custom data products using the SAP Datasphere Object Store, which supports zero-copy data access via the Delta Sharing Protocol - ensuring efficient, secure, and scalable data sharing across the enterprise.

SAP Databricks: SAP Databricks is a specialized integration of the Databricks platform embedded directly within SAP BDC. It combines industry-leading capabilities in AI, machine learning, data science, and data engineering with semantically rich, business-ready data from SAP applications. This component significantly enhances analytics by enabling generative AI scenarios‚Äîwithout the need for complex data pipelines. Through zero-copy Delta Sharing, SAP Databricks connects directly to SAP Data Products, allowing seamless access and enrichment of data without replication. By bridging enterprise-grade SAP data with the flexibility of Databricks, organizations can accelerate innovation, streamline operations, and unlock deeper insights across their business landscape.

SAP Analytics Cloud: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) empowers business analytics by directly consuming integrated data from the SAP Datasphere component within BDC. It supports rich visualization, reporting, and AI-driven analytics across the enterprise‚Äîall within a unified, cloud-based SaaS environment. By leveraging semantically aligned data from Datasphere, SAC enables organizations to generate actionable insights, build dynamic dashboards, and drive informed decision-making at scale.

SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA Integration: To support legacy compatibility, SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA objects can be technically onboarded into SAP BDC. This integration enables organizations to migrate data and maintain hybrid use cases‚Äîbridging traditional data warehousing with modern cloud-based analytics‚Äîuntil the official end-of-support timeline for BW systems. By incorporating BW artifacts into BDC, businesses can preserve existing investments while gradually transitioning to a unified, governed, and AI-ready data landscape.

Building Blocks of SAP Business Data Cloud

Provisioning an SAP Business Data Cloud Tenant

An SAP BDC tenant is provisioned via the SAP for Me portal using a guided, self-service workflow. This process enables organizations to activate and configure the components of SAP Business Data Cloud according to their commercial entitlements. The provisioning journey begins with the BDC Core Component or Cockpit, which serves as the central management interface for the entire SAP BDC landscape. 

Once the BDC cockpit is provisioned, the next step is to provision (from SAP for Me) the core capabilities and applications, including: SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks.

After these systems are successfully provisioned through SAP for Me, users can  begin creating Formations‚Äîstructured configurations that define how data products and applications are orchestrated across the landscape.

Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud

A Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud is a logical grouping of SAP systems and related components designed to support specific business scenarios or integration use cases. Formations simplify connectivity and provide a unified view of all systems, making it easier to manage integrations, extensions, and orchestrate data across the SAP BDC landscape.  Formations are created by selecting the required SAP systems‚Äîthese must first be provisioned via the SAP for Me portal. Once provisioned, they appear in the Systems tab of the portal and can be included in one or more formations. Each formation can consist of multiple systems such as SAP BDC Core, SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP BW, SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks. These systems are synchronized within the formation to enable streamlined operations and cohesive business processes. Multiple formations can be created to support extended or complex business scenarios.

Benefits of Using Formations

  • Simplified Integration: Centralizes the grouping and management of systems required for a business scenario.
  • Scalability and Flexibility: Easily add or remove systems as organizational needs evolve.
  • Governance and Control: Enables centralized configuration and oversight, improving compliance and reducing maintenance overhead.

SAP Data Products in Business Data Cloud 

An SAP Data Product is a curated and refined dataset derived from data ingested from SAP solutions. It encompasses a Business Data Set that includes master data, transactional records, analytics datasets, and configuration data‚Äîall semantically aligned to ensure consistency and usability.

These datasets are enriched with meaningful metadata and documentation, making them easily consumable and understandable. Within the SAP BDC, Data Products serve as the core building blocks for Intelligent Applications, enabling advanced analytics and decision-making.  SAP delivers and manages these Data Products as part of its SaaS offering, maintaining full lifecycle ownership. However, customers can customize them to suit specific business needs. Each Data Product includes all necessary artifacts‚Äîsuch as CDS views, connectors, flows, jobs, and lifecycle management tools‚Äîrequired to support its associated use cases within SAP BDC. They are easily discoverable through the SAP BDC product catalog. These products are designed by line-of-business experts to help organizations maximize the value of their data. Types of Data Products

  • Primary Data Products: Directly sourced from applications, representing original data from systems like SAP S/4HANA. They are not derived from other data products.
  • Derived Data Products: Built by SAP using existing datasets or APIs. This offer added value by combining or transforming data from multiple sources.

Custom or Customer Managed Data Products : SAP BDC also supports custom data products, which can be curated within SAP Datasphere. These leverage the Datasphere Object Store and Delta Sharing Protocol, enabling zero-copy data access for efficient and secure data sharing.

Intelligent Applications in SAP Business Data Cloud

Intelligent Applications are AI-driven, visualization-centric solutions designed to address specific business scenarios. Unlike general-purpose analytics tools, these applications are built with SAP-managed analytical assets and functionalities that deliver value through process, domain, or analytical intelligence. They typically include data products, semantic models, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) stories. These applications foster collaboration between analytics and data science teams by providing ready-made dashboards enriched with AI-generated insights. Their embedded business logic and contextual data models eliminate the need for organizations to build complex analytical frameworks from scratch‚Äîsaving time and resources. The core structure of Intelligent Applications includes:

  • SAC Stories: Serve as the front-end interface, offering rich visualizations tailored to specific analytics use cases.
  • SAP Datasphere Models and Views: Includes the backend logic and data orchestration.
  • Semantic Models and Story Templates: Combined to deliver reusable, customizable dashboards.

These applications are cataloged within the SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC), making them easy to discover, deploy, and extend.

Installation and Customization

To explore and install Intelligent Applications:

  1. Log in to the SAP BDC Cockpit. Browse the available applications and their documentation.
  2. Upon installation, a suite of artifacts is deployed across SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud, including Data Products, Replication Flows, Tables and Views, Analytic Models, Roles and Dashboards.

 Customization Guidelines

  • SAP-managed applications and their dependencies are read-only, but users can copy and adapt components.
  • SAC Stories can be duplicated and tailored to meet specific business needs.
  • For advanced scenarios, users may replicate and modify the underlying analytic models ( within SAP Datasphere).
  • Changes to models will affect both the original and copied stories, so version control and impact analysis are recommended.

Key Differentiation between Business Content and Intelligent Applications

  • Business Content provides a set of pre-built models and other artifacts, but customers manage the implementation, configuration and maintenance of these solutions.
  • Intelligent Applications are fully managed and curated by SAP and delivered as software-as-a-service designed to cater specific business use cases or scenarios.

Hope this helps you understand the basics and get started on SAP Business Data Cloud.

entry.title: Planning & Analytics (P&A) is an essential part of SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC)
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is crucial for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. The capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data is key success criteria. However, many companies struggle with data problems (fragmented information, outdated systems, and the challenge of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI).

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. The second blog post will summarise key arguments why Planning & Analytics (P&A) is an integral part of SAP BDC.

Picture 1: SAP BDC Intelligent Application - Working CapitalThere are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering
  2. Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world
  6. Move BPC and BW-IP into SAP BDC
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM use cases
  9. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

SAP BDC is equipped with powerful data management, planning & analytics (P&A), and innovative AI capabilities to tackle all these challenges and P&A is an essential part of SAP BDC. It provides transformative insights, seamless integration, AI augmentation, and enhanced data quality. These capabilities are crucial for effective business decision-making and strategic planning. Here are the key reasons why P&A is vital within SAP BDC:

Picture 2: SAP BDC high level architecture & flows in the context of business steering

  • Transformative Insights: P&A uncovers hidden insights using advanced analytics and planning applications across all lines of business. This capability allows organisations to make informed decisions based on comprehensive data analysis.
  • Seamless Integration: It combines SAP and third-party data to unify diverse data sources, enabling comprehensive analysis and a holistic view of business operations. This integration is crucial for maintaining data consistency and accuracy across the enterprise.
  • AI Augmentation: The integration of business AI, such as SAP‚Äôs AI copilot Joule, enhances decision-making by providing augmented insights and predictive capabilities. This helps businesses anticipate future trends and make proactive decisions.
  • Enhanced Data Quality: P&A automatically connects data across the business, ensuring accuracy and accelerating time to insight. This is essential for maintaining high data quality and reliability in business processes.
  • Agile Modelling and Predictive Analysis: Planning & Analytics supports agile data modelling aligned with analytics. It uses AI and machine learning to facilitate predictive analysis and simulation, enabling businesses to adapt quickly to changing conditions and optimise their strategies.
  • End-to-End Visibility: Planning & Analytics offers a 360-degree view of critical business processes with fully-managed, curated data products. This comprehensive visibility and control over operations provide businesses with a clear understanding of their performance.

Picture 3: SAP BDC - AI-powered Live-Planning & Analytics in SAP BDC

Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC, empowering organisations with the tools and insights needed to drive strategic initiatives, improve efficiency, and enhance decision-making across the enterprise.

The usage of Planning & Analytics (P&A) is therefore closely connected to the performance of an organisation and creation of business value through several key mechanisms that enhance decision-making, efficiency, and strategic alignment. Here‚Äôs how P&A impacts organisational performance:

  • Real-Time Insights: The ability to access real-time data and insights allows organisations to respond quickly to market changes and operational challenges. This agility is crucial for maintaining competitive advantage and optimising performance, especially in turbulent times like today.
  • Strategic Alignment: By aligning financial and operational plans with strategic objectives, P&A ensures that all parts of the organisation are working towards common goals. This alignment is critical for achieving long-term success and improving overall performance.
  • Data-Driven Decision Making: P&A tools provide a single source of truth for data, reducing the need for manual reconciliation and enabling more accurate and timely decision-making. This shift from manual processes to automated data integration enhances efficiency and reduces errors.
  • Improved Forecasting Accuracy: P&A tools, such as SAP Analytics Cloud, enable organisations to conduct predictive forecasting and scenario planning. This improves the accuracy of financial and operational forecasts, providing a forward-looking view of performance. This allows leaders to react promptly, leading to better resource allocation, strategic planning, and improved performance.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: By integrating planning processes across different departments, such as HR and finance, P&A fosters collaboration and alignment within the organisation. This integration helps create a unified approach to achieving business goals and improves communication across teams.
  • Increased Efficiency: Automation of planning processes reduces the time and effort required for data collection and analysis, allowing employees to focus on higher-value tasks such as strategic analysis and decision-making.

In summary, Planning & Analytics enhances organisational performance by improving forecasting accuracy, fostering collaboration, providing real-time insights, enabling data-driven forward looking decision-making, ensuring strategic alignment, and increasing efficiency. These benefits collectively contribute to a more agile, informed, and strategically aligned organisation.

Do you want to embark on a journey? Please reach out to your SAP representative and register for your SAP BDC Discovery Workshop!

In our next blog post, @Nektarios_Vasileiou33  will take you behind the scenes to unbox the key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC ‚Äî solutions that help businesses streamline planning, enhance decision-making, and foster cross-department collaboration. By exploring SAP BDC capabilities, you‚Äôll see how they drive more effective enterprise planning and analysis. Get ready for insights that unlock sharper strategies and smarter decisions. Stay tuned!

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Integration with SAP S/4HANA: SAP Cloud Connector Setup Guide
entry.content:
Introduction: 

In this article, we will explore SAP Cloud Connector what it is, its purpose, and the scenarios where it becomes essential. Whether you are working with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or connecting SAP S/4HANA on-premise systems to the cloud, the SAP Cloud Connector plays a critical role. We will also provide a step-by-step guide on its configuration and setup, helping you seamlessly bridge your on-premise and SAP Datasphere cloud environments.

What is SAP Cloud Connector?

The SAP Cloud Connector acts as a secure link between SAP Datasphere and on-premises systems, enabling seamless integration without exposing your entire internal network (behind the firewall). It runs as an on-premises agent or middleware in a secured environment and functions as a reverse invoke proxy, providing controlled access to selected systems and resources. 

Key benefits include fine-grained control over which on-premises systems cloud applications can access, automatic recovery of broken connections, and audit logging of inbound traffic and configuration changes. It also supports high-availability setups for enterprise scenarios.

Compared to opening firewall ports or using DMZ reverse proxies, the Cloud Connector is easier and safer to deploy. It supports multiple protocols, including HTTP and RFC for native ABAP system access, and allows secure propagation of cloud user identities to on-premises systems. With simple installation, low TCO, and standard SAP support, it‚Äôs an efficient solution for connecting cloud and on-premises landscapes.

Does it support data encryption ?

Yes, TLS encryption is used for the tunnel

What are the SAP Datasphere data integration features, and in which scenarios is the SAP Cloud Connector required?

  • Replication Flows ‚Äì For example, connecting to SAP ABAP CDS views and replicating data to the cloud.
  • Data Flows ‚Äì For scenarios like extracting, transforming, and loading data from on-premises sources, including SAP ABAP CDS views.
  • Model Import ‚Äì Importing existing ABAP CDS data models from on-premises systems into SAP Datasphere for further analytics and integration.

SAP Cloud Connector FAQs

Where can I find information about SAP Cloud Connector licensing, downloading, and installation ?

  • 2827108 - SAP Cloud Connector licensing, download and installation information.
  • It does not required separate license and it is free to use.
  • Download: SAP Cloud Connector.
  • Installation and Setup.

What are the Sizing Recommendations? 

  • Sizing for the Master Instance
  • Sizing for the Shadow Instance

What are the best practices and recommendations for setting up SAP Cloud Connector?

  • Always Use the Latest Version: Install or update to the latest Cloud Connector release to take advantage of new features and security improvements.
  • Dedicated Server Setup: Install on a dedicated server within your corporate network that has direct, unblocked access to the source system. Ideally, this server should be physically close to the source systems it connects to.
  • High Availability Setup:
    • Master (Primary Installation): Main Cloud Connector instance for normal or HA setups.
    • Shadow (Backup Installation): Secondary instance for HA, providing failover support.
  • Environment-Specific Installations: recommended to have a separate Cloud Connector for each environment (development, testing, production) to ensure stability and isolation.
  • User Configuration: Use an email ID linked to the subaccount or global account instead of an S-User for easier management.
  • Proper Sizing: Ensure the server has sufficient resources (CPU, memory, network bandwidth) to handle the expected load.
  • Regular Log Review: Continuously monitor logs and metrics to detect performance issues or connectivity problems and resolve them promptly.

SAP Cloud Connector Troubleshooting Guides:

  • Common Issues and Guided Answers.
  • Logs and Troubleshooting.
  • 3369433 - How to troubleshoot Cloud Connector related issues when creating connection in SAP Datasphere

Steps to Install, Configure and Setup the SAP Cloud Connector:

Step 1: Download, Prerequisites, and Install the Cloud Connector

Before you begin configuration, make sure the following prerequisites are in place:

  • Download: SAP Cloud Connector.
  • The Cloud Connector is installed in your on-premise network. (See Cloud Connector Installation in the SAP BTP Connectivity documentation.)
  • If you‚Äôre using egress firewalling, add these domains to the firewall/proxy allowlist:
    •  *.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    • *.k8s-hana.ondemand.com
  • You need an SAP BTP account. If you don‚Äôt already have one, create it by registering in the SAP BTP cockpit.

Step 2: Launch and Login

  • After installation, an user:Administrator account is created with the initial password: manage (case-sensitive). You‚Äôll be prompted to change it on first login. Default/Initial login details Administrator / manage 

  • Access the Cloud Connector Administration at:
    https://<hostname>:8443 (replace <hostname> with the machine name, or use localhost if installed locally).

  • 2388242 - KBA: How to reset SAP Cloud Connector built-in user's password

Step 3: Add Your SAP BTP Subaccount

You‚Äôll need details from your SAP Datasphere subaccount:

  • Subaccount

  • Region Host ( Data Center - Providers and Regions)

  • Sub Account User (usually the email ID tied to your BTP account)

If account info is missing, enter your SAP BTP user ID manually. For troubleshooting, see KBA: 2397165.

2571763 - Authorization problem in SAP Cloud Connector when adding Cloud Foundry subaccount

For auth errors refer Log and Trace Files: scc_core.trc

Note: Initially SAP BTP Core account details in SAP Datasphere will not be available, you must provide the SAP BTP account email and save. SAP Datasphere tenant owner can perform this.

 

 

Step 4: Verify Connection

Once the subaccount is added, the status should display Connected.

 

Step 5: Configure the Cloud Connector

For this guide, we‚Äôll focus on Replication Flow scenarios using RFC and HTTPS protocols.

 

Step 6: Add the SAP S/4HANA (ABAP) System

  1. Select Cloud to On-Premise scenario and Back-end Type: ABAP System.

     

  2. Choose HTTPS protocol.

     

  3. Use without load balancing (application server + instance number).

     

  4. Enter your SAP S/4HANA internal host and port.

    How to find internal host and port from SAP S/4HANA ? (Run T-Code SMICM ‚Üí Services).

     

  5. Leaving defaults for principal propagation and system certificate. (check your requirement and change)

     

  6. Define a virtual host name (recommended: different from the internal name).

     

     

  7. Provide a System ID (e.g., RI4) and description, then finish setup.

     

  8. Test connectivity ‚Äì status should show Reachable.

     

  9. Add resources ‚Äì in this scenario, we added all resources under /.

     

Step 7: Add RFC Protocol Resources

  1. Select RFC protocol.

     

  2. Enter system mapping details (System ID + description).

     

  3. Finish setup and test connectivity.

     

      

  4. Map required resources:

     

    • With Prefix (e.g., DHAMB_)

        

    • With Exact Name (e.g., RFC_FUNCTION_SEARCH)

       

  5. Ensure the status turns Green for all resources.

     

Step 8: Maintain IP Allow list in SAP Datasphere

  1. Identify the public IP address of the host where Cloud Connector is installed (e.g., via whatismyip.com or ip.me or whatever way you are aware of).

     

  2. Add this IP under Trusted Cloud Connector IPs in SAP Datasphere:
    System ‚Üí Configuration ‚Üí IP Allowlist.

     

Step 9: Maintain the Cloud Connector Location ID in SAP Datasphere

Go to:
SAP Datasphere ‚ÜíSystem ‚Üí Administration ‚Üí Data Source Configuration and maintain the Cloud Connector Location ID.

 

 

With these steps completed, your SAP Cloud Connector is successfully installed, connected, and configured to integrate and create a native connection type of SAP S/4HANA on-premise with SAP Datasphere.

Summary: 

In this blog, we saw how the SAP Cloud Connector helps connect SAP Datasphere with on-premise systems in a secure and easy way. It supports features like Replication Flows, Data Flows, and Model Import for smooth data integration. We also looked at the benefits such as simple setup, better security, high availability, and low cost. With best practices like keeping it updated, using a dedicated server, and regular monitoring, you can ensure reliable performance. Finally, we walked through the step-by-step setup to successfully link SAP S/4HANA with SAP Datasphere.

entry.title: O que √© o SAP Datasphere?
entry.content:
‚ÄÉIntrodu√ß√£o

O SAP Datasphere √© a solu√ß√£o mais recente da SAP para gest√£o de dados corporativos, criada para habilitar uma arquitetura de business data fabric. Essa arquitetura permite harmonizar dados cr√≠ticos de neg√≥cios em toda a organiza√ß√£o, ajudando empresas a tomar decis√µes mais r√°pidas e precisas.

O Contexto de Neg√≥cio

Compreender o contexto de neg√≥cio no SAP Datasphere √© fundamental para aproveitar seu potencial. Seja voc√™ arquiteto de solu√ß√µes, engenheiro de dados ou analista, esta plataforma oferece recursos que simplificam a integra√ß√£o, governan√ßa e consumo de dados em escala.

O que √© o SAP Datasphere?

O SAP Datasphere re√∫ne em um √∫nico servi√ßo recursos antes separados, como:

  • Integra√ß√£o de dados
  • Cataloga√ß√£o
  • Modelagem sem√¢ntica
  • Data warehousing

A solu√ß√£o foi desenhada para combinar federation e ingestion de dados SAP e n√£o-SAP, preservando o contexto e o significado dos dados, independentemente do sistema ou nuvem em que se encontram. Isso elimina a necessidade de replicar dados em mais um reposit√≥rio, simplificando a landscape de dados e garantindo governan√ßa desde a origem at√© o consumo.

Evolu√ß√£o: Do SAP Data Warehouse Cloud ao SAP Datasphere

Em 2019, a SAP lan√ßou o SAP Data Warehouse Cloud, primeira solu√ß√£o de data warehousing totalmente em nuvem. J√° em 2023, foi apresentado o SAP Datasphere, sucessor l√≥gico que adiciona recursos avan√ßados de integra√ß√£o e cataloga√ß√£o de dados.

O SAP Datasphere foi projetado para colaborar com ferramentas externas, como:

  • Collibra ‚Äì Governan√ßa e cataloga√ß√£o de dados
  • Databricks ‚Äì Integra√ß√£o com Data Lakehouse para machine learning
  • Confluent ‚Äì Streaming e eventos em tempo real
  • DataRobot ‚Äì Intelig√™ncia aumentada com AutoML
  • Google Cloud ‚Äì Integra√ß√£o completa com BigQuery e AI para criar um data cloud de ponta a ponta

Essa abordagem refor√ßa a estrat√©gia de abertura e interoperabilidade, permitindo que empresas aproveitem ao m√°ximo seus investimentos j√° existentes em dados.

Arquitetura do SAP Datasphere

A arquitetura combina:

  • Funcionalidades de banco de dados (SAP HANA Cloud)
  • Modelagem de dados com ferramentas low-code/no-code
  • Integra√ß√£o nativa com o SAP Analytics Cloud para relat√≥rios e planejamento

Os principais blocos funcionais s√£o:

  • Space Management ‚Äì Cria√ß√£o e monitoramento de espa√ßos seguros para modelagem de dados
  • Data Integration e Data Flow ‚Äì Conex√£o com fontes SAP e n√£o-SAP, replica√ß√£o em tempo real e transforma√ß√µes
  • Data Builder ‚Äì Modelagem t√©cnica e harmoniza√ß√£o de dados
  • Data Catalog ‚Äì Organiza√ß√£o e governan√ßa de metadados para promover confian√ßa e reutiliza√ß√£o
  • Data Marketplace ‚Äì Integra√ß√£o simples com dados de terceiros
  • Administra√ß√£o e Seguran√ßa ‚Äì Controle de acessos, auditoria e conformidade
  • Semantic Onboarding ‚Äì Importa√ß√£o de objetos sem√¢nticos de sistemas SAP e marketplaces
  • Consumo ‚Äì Conex√£o com SAP Analytics Cloud ou outras ferramentas de BI via SQL ou APIs

Benef√≠cios para Empresas

Com o SAP Datasphere, organiza√ß√µes conseguem:

  • Reduzir complexidade da landscape de dados
  • Preservar o contexto de informa√ß√µes cr√≠ticas
  • Garantir governan√ßa em todas as etapas do ciclo de vida dos dados
  • Integrar e consumir dados em tempo real
  • Facilitar o autosservi√ßo de modelagem para usu√°rios de neg√≥cio

Conclus√£o

O SAP Datasphere √© mais que uma evolu√ß√£o do SAP Data Warehouse Cloud ‚Äì √© uma plataforma completa para integra√ß√£o, governan√ßa e consumo de dados, projetada para um mundo multicloud e multisource.

Ele oferece √†s empresas uma base s√≥lida para transformar dados em vantagem competitiva, combinando simplicidade, escalabilidade e flexibilidade para atender desde necessidades operacionais at√© iniciativas estrat√©gicas de an√°lise e planejamento.

entry.title: Building Custom LLM Agent in Databricks: An Example Generating AI Responses from Customer Review
entry.content:
Hi Everyone!
As we know that Large Language Models (LLMs) are changing how businesses work with data and with Agent Bricks in Databricks, we can build smart agents that understand our specific business needs and are part of our data workflows. Using Generative AI, these agents can create insights, answer questions, and suggest actions, turning raw data into useful, actionable information.

Now let's deep dive into what Agent Bricks is and see how it can be put to work.

1. What is Agent Bricks?
Agent Bricks provides a simple way to build and optimize domain-specific, high-quality AI agent systems, allowing us to package LLM-based agents as reusable building blocks for common AI applications. It leverages Databricks Mosaic AI, enabling us to quickly and easily deploy comprehensive AI agent systems tailored to our unique data.
Source:
Databricks - Agent Bricks

2. Using Agent Bricks
Let us start by creating a custom LLM agent
Step 1: Identify use case

  • Define the specific purpose of your agent
  • Example: Generate AI-driven responses based on customer reviews
  • Specify the input data (e.g., customer reviews) and expected output (e.g., responses to reviews)

Lets decide our use case of "Generating AI responses from customer reviews"

Step 2: Create a labeled dataset
For our use case, we need a table with customer name and order review. As the agent accepts only one input, we have combined customer name and order review in one column called "customer_review"

Step 3: Creating a custom LLM model 
We will click on Agents tab on the left and then select Build under custom LLM model

After that in the next screen, we will enter an agent name and provide the instruction set in "Describe your task" section

The instruction set used is provided below:

You are a customer support assistant writing a response to a customer review. You are given a text where the customer name and their review are concatenated in one column.
The format is always:
<Customer Name>|<Customer Review>

    "Your task:
    1. Split the text into two parts: "customer name" and "review"
    2. Begin the response by greeting the customer using their name (e.g., 'Dear John,').
    2. Write a warm, professional and empathetic response acknowledging the customer's concern in English.
    3. Acknowledge the customer‚Äôs frustration and **apologize sincerely**.
    4. **Reassure the customer** that their concern is being taken seriously and that the issue will be reviewed to prevent recurrence.
    5. Keep the tone friendly, concise, and polite.
    6. If no follow-up reason is provided or the review is positive, write a kind Thank-you message instead.
    7. Keep the response under 100 words.

    Your response must show **genuine concern and accountability**. Always respond in fluent English.
    In the output update only response and nothing else")

After that we select the labeled dataset option and provide table name, input column and output column as shown below, and then click on Create Agent. If we want we can also use unstructured data like PDFs for our analysis by selecting unlabeled dataset.

Step 4: Train the Agent
In the next screen, we will review the guidelines created based on the instruction set and additionally more guidelines can be added. We then review the response provided by the agent to improve quality of the agent. This allows the agent to learn patterns from examples while following our custom guidelines.

We can also go to Quality Report tab to analyze the checks we have done and how is the agent performing as per our requirement

Step 5: Optimizing the agent
We can optimize the agent to be more cost effective thus saving us costs. Click on Optimize tab and select Start Optimization.

Once optimizations is complete, we can compare the quality of new agent based on our baseline agent and if it meets our requirement, we can deploy the optimized agent.

Step 6: Using the agent
We can try using the Agent by clicking on Use button as highlighted below. We can use the Agent using SQL, create an ETL Pipeline or use the agent in AI Playground.

Let's use the SQL option for our use case. Below query is generated in a new SQL editor using the custom endpoint created for our agent as highlighted below and uses the table that it is built on for testing

3. Using Agent Bricks in SQL
Once the agent is ready, we can use it via SQL in multiple ways.
First, let's create a SQL function using the custom end point of the agent and the SQL AI function "ai_query". This function will accept customer review as an input and generate AI response for each customer review.


Now lets create a table using the custom endpoint of the agent so that we can generate AI responses for all the customer reviews and save it in a table.

4. Benefits of using Agent Bricks:

  • Consistency & Reliability - Agent Bricks ensures that responses follow the rules every time. For example, if our guideline says ‚Äúalways include the customer‚Äôs name in the response,‚Äù the agent enforces it.
  • Reusability Across Teams -  Once created, an Agent can be reused by different teams or workflows without rebuilding  the prompt. This reduces duplication and speeds up agent adoption across the organization.
  • Quality Control - Agent can be reviewed, fine-tuned, and evaluated systematically for controlling the desired output.
  • Cost Optimization - Agent can be optimized to reduce costs and it can also save costs by using batch processing.

5. Alternative to Agent Bricks
We can alternatively create a custom SQL AI function using an LLM like LlaMA model and AI_QUERY function to achieve the same output. For example, we can write a SQL function that takes the customer name and review text as input and returns an AI-generated response.

We can then use the created function to generate the customer response

This function works fine but it has some drawbacks:

  • No Quality Testing - The output cannot be systematically tested or reviewed for quality as we cannot provide feedback to the SQL AI function.
  • Inconsistent Results - It is harder to ensure the responses follow consistent rules across large datasets.
  • Higher Cost Risk - It can have higher cost risk as each SQL query call processes data row by row.

5. Integration with SAP BDC
Currently, Agents is still in Preview in Databricks and is not available in SAP Databricks.
We hope that it becomes GA and be made available in SAP Databricks also.

As an alternate, for now, we can regenerate customer response table generated above using SQL function instead of agent and then we can share this table back to BDC using the SAP BDC connector.
We can then use this table as a data product for our case in our dashboards or reports.
Source:
SAP - Sharing Data Products from SAP Databricks to SAP Business Data Cloud 
Databricks -  Share data between SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and Databricks


We can also watch the below video shared by Arijit Banerjee that was presented by him in this year's Databricks Tech Summit:

This video clearly explains how we can share data products from SAP BDC to SAP Databricks and then make changes in Databricks and share the new tables back to SAP BDC.

Conclusion:
Agent Bricks in Databricks allows businesses to:

  • Customize AI agents with labeled or unlabeled datasets and clear instructions
  • Review and refine outputs for reliability
  • Deploy agents directly in SQL for scalable automation
  • Reduce costs by optimizing the agent

By combining data and AI, Agent Bricks helps us to unlock a new level of automation and personalization for modern businesses.

entry.title: Unsupported Features with SAP Datasphere Live Connections in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Cloud folks,

I would like to share some of the information that i searched for..

I faced lot of question after implementing SAC Stories on Live connection and this article helps to them.

when working with an SAC live connection to SAP Datasphere, you experience certain product limitations in SAC

In general, any SAP Datasphere system can be connected to any SAC system via the SAP Datasphere live connection in SAC.
Live connections between SAC and SAP Datasphere can be established across tenants . When using the SAC


‚Äì Datasphere live connection, We can build SAC stories or analytical applications that, at the same time, use data from a SAP
Datasphere space, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces in multiple SAP Dataspheres as well as
any additional data sources that you have connected to SAC

When using the SAC ‚Äì Datasphere live connection, SAC currently has the following product limitations:

Below are the list of  features that are not supported 

Analytics : 
Custom Shapes for Geo Maps are not supported
Version based variance features are not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Version Mapping is not supported for SAP Datasphere data.
Blending is not supported.
Scheduling a Publication is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Linked Dimension is only supported for SAP Datasphere models from the same Space. It is not supported across Spaces.
R-Visualizations are not supported. Note: you can vote for this enhancement request here.
Comment Widgets are not supported
Copy Widgets between stories is not supported
Import Pages from Stories that contain Datasphere models is not supported

JustAsk : 
On-the-fly search with Datasphere models is supported.
Indexing Datasphere models in SAC JustAsk is not supported.
Open in Data Analyzer is not supported
Copy widget to Story is not supported
Stories in Classic Experience
Blending is supported for the following scenarios
SAP Datasphere data with local SAC data
SAP Datasphere data with SAP Datasphere data from the same Datasphere space.
Blending information across Datasphere spaces, or across Datasphere tenants, or blending of Datasphere data with
other Live Connections is not supported.
Using Hyperlinks with the option "Apply selected dimension as filter" enabled across Stories using SAP Datasphere Live
Connections is not supported.
SAP Datasphere Analytic models are not supported

SAP Datasphere Data Types
The following SAP Datasphere Data types are currently not supported in SAP Analytics Cloud:
Bigint
Binary
hana.binary
Large Binary
Large String


Planning
SAC Planning data can now be stored in Datasphere with seamless planning However, planning
still requires the import of data into the SAC model and is not based on the SAP Datasphere live connection 


Smart features
Smart Insights are not supported on SAP Datasphere data. .
Smart Discovery is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Smart Predict is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
SAP Digital Boardroom
Stories built on top of SAP Datasphere live data are not supported in SAP Digital Boardroom.

Regards,

Kartheek Kota

Reference:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2832606

entry.title: Archive SAC Change Docs into Datasphere
entry.content:
Using SAC data change documents, you can track (audit) the data changes made to any planning model. SAP Analytics Cloud logs all changes to the transaction data of that model when users publish data from private versions to public versions.

Note that a data change log has up to 2^31 (i.e., 2,147,384,648, or ~2 billion) records. When the data change log reaches its size limit, publishing data will fail, and you will see the following message:

Publish cannot be performed because the data audit table has reached the maximum number of rows.

To avoid this issue, consider periodically downloading log entries as a backup before deleting them.

This document shows a design to back up SAC audit logs into Datasphere. Using Datasphere dataflow to back up change documents from the SAC Data Export Service via a Cloud Data Integration adapter-based connection, it can back up and preserve the SAC audit log history, which is necessary for regular housekeeping in SAC due to storage capacity limits.

 

DES: data export service

CDI: cloud data integration

 

Note: In SAC seamless planning or in BDC, the SAC model definition and calculation logic remain within SAC, while the persistence for planning data and change documents are stored in SAP Datasphere, so that both systems are closely linked - without the effort of manual data transfers. Therefore, the solution might not be necessary if the SAC change documents are already stored in Datasphere.

 

The following steps outline the implementation of the solution.

In SAC, System ‚Äì Administration ‚Äì App Integration, create an OAuth client with Access to the Data Export Service.

 

 

In SAC, keep the OAuth Client URLs for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

 

In SAC, copy the OAuth Client ID and Client Secret for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

In Datasphere, in a space, create a Cloud Data Integration connection pointing to the SAC Data Export Service. The URL is in the format of

https://<your domain>/api/v1/dataexport/administration

 

In the connections management screen, validate the connection, and make sure the Data Flows feature is now enabled. It shall give the following message after validation on the connection.

Connection ‚ÄúSAC DES Change Docs‚Äù is valid. ‚Äì Data flows are enabled. ‚Äì Replication flows are not supported. ‚Äì Remote tables are enabled.

 

In SAC, open the model with the Audit Data flag switched on, and note down the model ID in the rear part of the URL. For instance:

https://<your domain name>/sap/fpa/ui/app.html?sap-ui-theme=sap_belize#/modeler&/m/model/C4003n1icbi0loo9lvgv7t4pu41

 

In Datasphere, Data Builder- Create a Data Flow to load SAC audit logs into a target table.

  1. Use the model id to find the SAC source in the connection for the source node in the data flow.
  2. To make the daily backup more efficient, an exemplary expression implemented in the projection node can be: "Audit_Time" >= ADD_DAYS(NOW(), -1).
  3. To preserve the audit logs history that might be regularly cleaned in SAC, use Append mode on the target table for UPSERT.

 

 

 

In Datasphere, execute the data flow to load SAC audit logs and verify that the data is now present in Datasphere. Then, delete the audit logs in SAC, execute the data flow again to check that the audit logs history has been preserved after cleansing audit logs in SAC.

 

Last but not least, you may also develop an analytic model on top of the audit logs history table in Datasphere for analytics and build a report or visualization in SAC.

Note:

CDI connection type also supports the remote table as well as the data flow feature.

Remote table can use the following replication types, but none of those replications can well preserve the change document history.

  • Replication (snapshot)
  • Replication (real-time)

entry.title: From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach
entry.content:
From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach

We recently wrote a blog about how we integrate data from a REST service into SAP Datasphere. For that we deployed a small service on SAP BTP, which used the OPEN SQL schema and FastAPI to write this data directly into Datasphere. That service could also be triggered via REST endpoint from SAP Datasphere directly (ZPARTNER Link, SAP Community Link).

In this blog we now choose a different setup to retrieve data and consume it into SAP Dataphere.

We Created a CAP Application on SAP BTP.

This CAP service connects to the SCIM API of SAP Datasphere, extracts users and roles, and makes the data consumable for analytics. It uses the following BTP services:

  • HDI Container
    To persist our data from the REST calls. The HDI container is deployed to the HANA Cloud instance of our Datasphere tenant, so the data can be consumed directly.
  • BTP Credential Store
    We store the credentials for the SCIM API in the BTP Credential Store and retrieve them in our CAP application securely.
  • XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management
    To secure our REST endpoints and enforce token-based access control.
  • Cloud Foundry Space
    Provides the runtime environment for deploying the CAP application.

Use Case

In our use case, we extract user information from SAP Datasphere‚Äôs own SCIM API.

We retrieve:

  • the list of users,
  • all available roles, and
  • the assignments between users and roles.

This can be helpful for reporting on the number of users in a tenant and their corresponding roles. However, the same setup can be reused to extract and process any other REST API data into SAP Datasphere.

Credential Store

We create a dedicated namespace in the Credential Store and store four secrets for the SCIM API authentication flow:

  • dsp-scim-token-url
  • dsp-scim-base-url
  • dsp-scim-client-id
  • dsp-scim-client-secret

The CAP application retrieves these secrets at runtime, ensuring no credentials are hardcoded.

XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management Service

We create a dedicated xsuaa service to get a Token URL and credentials. This service is bound to our CAP application so that every incoming request is authorized and protected.

HDI Container

We create an HDI container where the database artifacts (tables and associations) are deployed. This container is provisioned in our SAP Datasphere tenant, making the synchronized data directly available for consumption.

CAP Application

The heart of the solution is the CAP service DSPUsers.

It exposes two kinds of endpoints:

Virtual Views (live from SCIM)

  • GET /data/UsersVH ‚Üí List of users with profile info.
  • GET /data/RolesVH ‚Üí Roles with aggregated user counts.
  • GET /data/UserRolesVH ‚Üí Which users have which roles.

These views are always fresh, since they query SCIM directly.

Persistent Entities (stored in HDI)

  • GET /data/Users ‚Üí Users persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/Roles ‚Üí Roles persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/UserRoles ‚Üí User-to-role assignments persisted in HANA.

Actions (to sync SCIM ‚Üí HDI)

  • POST /data/SyncUsersVHToUsers ‚Üí Upserts SCIM users into the Users table.
  • POST /data/SyncRolesFromSCIM ‚Üí Stores aggregated roles in the Roles table.
  • POST /data/SyncUserRolesFromSCIM ‚Üí Refreshes both Roles and UserRoles.

This design lets you both query SCIM data live and persist snapshots into HANA for modeling in Datasphere.

The complete CAP service code is available here: Link to GitHub Repository.

SAP Datasphere

Once deployed, the HDI container is automatically integrated with our SAP Datasphere tenant. This allows:

  • Consuming the Users, Roles, and UserRoles tables directly in Datasphere,
  • Building reporting scenarios on top of user and role data,
  • Joining with other business data to enrich analytics.

To consume the entities, we need to add the HDI Container to a specific space. Also, we can now create a generic HTTP Connection. This enables to call the Endpoints for sync in a Task Chain.

Conclusion

The integration of a CAP-based service into SAP Datasphere showcases how SAP BTP services (HDI Container, Credential Store, XSUAA, Cloud Foundry) can be combined to securely retrieve and persist data from external REST APIs. By consuming SAP Datasphere‚Äôs own SCIM API, we demonstrated how to expose both live views for real-time insights and persistent tables for analytical modeling, all within a lightweight and extensible architecture.

Looking ahead, this framework can be reused for any REST API integration into SAP Datasphere, opening the door to richer reporting scenarios, advanced data modeling, and seamless orchestration with Task Chains. With this foundation, organizations gain a simple but powerful pattern for bridging external services with Datasphere while maintaining enterprise-grade security and governance.

entry.title: üåü Highlights: Enterprise Architects Guide on SAP BW Modernization üåü
entry.content:
We wrapped up an in-depth session ‚Äì expertly introduced by Gaurish ‚Äì on ‚ÄúArchitecting your SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Journey from Data to Intelligence." Sandy, Justin, and Jason shared practical viewpoints for anyone charting a course from legacy SAP BW to the world of SAP‚Äôs Business Data Cloud.

üîç Why Modernize SAP BW?
Justin emphasized how SAP BW has shaped enterprise analytics for 25+ years. However, remaining on legacy systems increases risks and costs, while stifling innovation. The move to modern, multi-cloud data platforms is essential to sustain business continuity and stay competitive.

üöÄ Unveiling the SAP Business Data Cloud Advantage
Modernizing to BDC offers a unified and scalable SaaS platform that blends SAP and non-SAP data, infuses AI and machine learning, and boosts analytics and data governance. It preserves business relationships and metadata, providing more business context than ever possible with classic BW.

üõ£Ô∏è Strategic Pathways & Migration Options
Successful modernization starts with a BW landscape assessment. SAP supports this with a free assessment and discovery workshop to catalogue your environment and match the right transition pathway‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs greenfield, system conversion, or embedded scenarios. Focus is on minimizing business disruption and maximizing long-term agility.

üõ†Ô∏è The Data Product Generator in Action
Sandy‚Äôs live demo showed how the Data Product Generator lets organizations extract BW InfoProvider data into SAP Datasphere‚Äôs object store - supporting cost-effective storage and simplified creation of data products ready for analytics and AI in Databricks, Datashare, and more.

üîó Smooth BW-BDC Transitions & Reference Patterns
The ability to push data from BW into BDC via dedicated inbound spaces, define granular subscriptions, and link to intelligent applications in SAC allows gradual, disruption-minimized modernization. Sandy outlined technical steps, naming conventions, and how semantic information and associations enhance downstream analytics.

üèõÔ∏è Enterprise Architecture Viewpoints
Jason gave a holistic lens on this transformation, urging enterprise architects to align their strategy on security, governance, business stakeholder impact, and organizational change management. Modernization isn‚Äôt just about technology‚Äîit‚Äôs about culture, skills, and sustainable strategic alignment.

üéâ Customer Success, Services & What‚Äôs Next
SAP‚Äôs BDC Discovery Workshop and free readiness assessment were spotlighted‚Äîhelping organizations begin their modernization journey with confidence. Participants gained clarity on prerequisites for custom data products, and how future capabilities like the Data Product Studio will shape self-service data management.

SAP Migration Assessment: https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/sap-migration-assessment.html

üôåHuge thanks to everyone who joined and asked great questions! Special thanks to Sandy for the impromptu deep dive and hands-on demo.


üëâStay tuned for the next session: ‚ÄúFast Track to SAP Business Data Cloud‚Äù featuring fresh perspectives from the Data & Analytics community.

Registration Link: https://events.sap.com/eaa-bdc-apac/en_us/home.html#accordion-5d79451476-item-7fc89659c4

 @Gaurish-Dessai  @SandyTran @Justin_Zhang1

entry.title: Integrating SAP Datasphere with S/4HANA in ECS
entry.content:
Integrating SAP S/4 HANA with Datasphere in ECS:

Introduction

In today's data-driven business landscape, seamless integration between enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems and advanced analytics platforms is crucial for unlocking real-time insights and driving informed decision-making. SAP Datasphere, a cloud-based data management solution, offers powerful capabilities for data modelling, federation, and replication. SAP Datasphere integration enables SAP S/4HANA system and the organizations to harmonize data from core business operations with broader analytics workflows, all, while maintaining security and compliance.

Objective of this guide is to serve as a walkthrough guide for integrating S/4HANA system  with SAP Datasphere. However, please note that this guide is for information purpose only and the configuration steps in customers‚Äô responsibility should be followed up by the customers accordingly.

Architecture Diagram

Prerequisites for Integration

Before diving into the setup, please note that, for the convenience of this guide and to be in sync with the terms, here on, we will assume S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition at ECS as S/4HANA system. Which also implies customer‚Äôs current landscape (when referred as on-premise) is ‚ÄòECS‚Äô- a managed private cloud.

  1. SAP Datasphere Service Instance: Customer should have already completed the onboarding of SAP Datasphere. It runs on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
  2. Data Provisioning (DP) Agent:  Required for handling remote table data flow between on-premise and cloud. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  3. SAP Cloud Connector: Required to securely expose on-premise systems to the cloud without opening firewalls (reverse invoke) used for replication and live data flow connections. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  4. Network and Access: All applicable secure network connections between S/4HANA and Datasphere based on relevant dataflows to be taken care.
    Ex: CC for inbound dataflows from BTP to ECS and outbound internet proxy for outbound traffic from ECS to Datasphere. Also IP allowlisting for the DP Agent server and likewise.

4.1       IP allowlisting Process:

In order to connect ECS instance to datasphere tenant, it requires public IP associated with customer network‚Äôs internet proxy of the ECS servers to be added in IP allowlist tab in datasphere.

This is the public IP of their CGS proxy server. Customer can follow KBA 3643152 to get this public IP.

After getting this IP, log in to Datasphere tenantÔÉ† System ÔÉ† Configuration ÔÉ† IP Allowlist ÔÉ† Trusted Ips

 

  • SAP Notes and Add-ons: Implement relevant SAP Notes (e.g., 3283282 for CDS views, 3016862 for ABAP integration) in S/4HANA system and ensure the DMIS add-on is available for replication scenarios.
  • SICF services for live connection : Ensure all SICF services under the node /sap/bw/ina are activated in the S/4HANA system.
  • User Permissions: Administrative access in Datasphere, S/4HANA, and BTP

Integration Steps

The integration process involves configuring connectivity, setting up agents, and creating connections in Datasphere. Here's a detailed technical walkthrough

Step 1: Set Up Spaces in SAP Datasphere

  • Navigate to Space Management in Datasphere.
  • Create a new space and assign users to it. This space will host your data models and connections.

 

Step 2: Register and Configure the Data Provisioning Agent

  • In Datasphere, go to System > Configuration > Data Integration and create an On-Premise Agent.
  • Note the agent details: Name, HANA server (host), port, username, and password for messaging.
  • On the DP Agent server:
    • Run ./agentcli.sh ‚ÄìconfigAgent in the /usr/sap/<SID>/dataprovagent/bin directory.

    • Select SAP HANA Connection > 7. Connect to SAP Datasphere via JDBC.

 

  1. Specify the details according to information provided by customer:
  1. Name of the agent instance.
  2. Set " true" to use an encrypted connection over JDBC.
  3. Specify the hostname and port for the  SAP Datasphere  instance.
    • Hostname: <instance_name>.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    • Port Number: 443
  4. As SAP Datasphere is situated outside the ECS network infrastructure, a proxy is required for HTTPS communication. Define the default CGS proxy host - proxy:3128 (no authentication required)
  5. Provide the authentication credentials for the HANA User for Agent Messaging.
  6.  Confirm to save the agent connection settings. With that any existing agent connection settings are overwritten.

  • Restart the DP Agent.
  • Enable required adapters (e.g., ABAPAdapter for S/4HANA).

 

Step 3: Configure SAP Cloud Connector

  • To configure cloud connector we need the information of Datasphere‚Äôs internal Subaccount details. This can be found under Datasphere tenant, System ÔÉ† Administration ÔÉ†Data source Configuration ÔÉ† SAP BTP Core Account

        

 

  • If the email ID which will be used to setup cloud connector is not visible under the Subaccount User header, use the Change/Add Cloud Platform User option to the respective ID.
  • Under the Live Data Sources header select the ‚ÄòAllow live data to securely leave my network‚Äô option
  • Under On-Premise Data Sources header add the location ID you will be using in your cloud connector if any.

 

  • Add the subaccount in Cloud connector using the Subaccount ID, Region Host and user information from above.
  • Add the same location ID as configured in the previous step.

  • Add your on-premise S/4HANA system in the Cloud Connector:
    • Use HTTPS and RFC protocols.
    • System type: ABAP.
    • For HTTPS ‚Äú/‚Äù URL path needs to be exposed for all Paths and Sub-Paths
    • For RFC protocol add resources as below-
      • ‚ÄòDHAMB_‚Äô and ‚ÄòDHAPE_‚Äô with prefix for CDS view extraction.
      • ‚ÄòLTAMB_‚Äô and ‚ÄòLTAPE_‚Äô with prefix option for accessing tables with SLT.
      • ‚Äò/SAPDS/‚Äô with prefix option for accessing data with ODP.
      • Add RFC_FUNCTION_SEARCH with exact name option for all three options.
  • Ensure both RFC and HTTPS resources are reachable.

Step 4: Prepare S/4HANA for Connectivity

  • Create a TCP/IP RFC connection in S/4HANA using program ID IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER.
  • Register the program at the OS level: rfcexec -a IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER -g <Hostname> -x SAPGW<Instance no.> -s <SID> &.
  • Test the RFC connection.

Step 5: Create the Connection in SAP Datasphere to S/4H

To create live data connection from datasphere to backend S4 system in ECS, it uses SSH tunnel via Cloud connector

In your Datasphere space, select System > Configuration ÔÉ† Data Integration.

  • Go to Live Data Connections (Tunnel) click on ‚ÄúManage Live Data Connections‚Äù  A window opens click on ‚Äú+‚Äù a pop up opens, select SAP S/4 HANA

  • For live data: using a Tunnel connection enter the Location ID maintained in Cloud connector
  • Input application server details, system number, client ID, SID,
  • Provide S/4HANA username and password.

 

 

 

After you click on Ok it adds the connection

 

Step 6: Set Up Data Flows and Models

  • Use Remote Tables for federation or Replication Flows for data replication (supporting initial and delta loads via CDC).
  • Import CDS views using the Model Import Wizard to automatically bring in metadata and semantics.
